metadata.title: External location of touch is constructed post-hoc based on limb choice

body_text.text: Spatial perception and actions rely on multiple spatial codes, often 17 associated with different reference frames. For instance, the accuracy of pointing 18 or reaching with an arm or finger to a visual target depends not only on the position 19 of target relative to gaze (Fiehler et al., 2011; Thompson et al., 2014) , but also on 20 salient world-centered landmarks (Schütz et al., 2013) . Similarly, judgment of 21 visual location during whole-body movement is influenced by a target's position 22 relative to gaze, as well as by the location of the target relative to the body 23 (Tramper & Medendorp, 2015) . 24

In touch, too, space is coded in several reference frames. Touch activates 25 specialized sensory receptors embedded in the skin, and the arrangement of the 26 peripheral sensors is reflected in the homuncular organization of primary 27 somatosensory cortex (Penfield & Boldrey, 1937; Roux et al., 2018) , referred to as 28 a skin-based or somatotopic layout. However, because our body can take various 29 postures, the stimulus location in space -often referred to as its external location 30 -must be derived by combining skin location and body posture, a process termed 31 tactile remapping (Heed, Buchholz, et al., 2015) . Indeed, there is evidence that 32 external tactile locations can be coded in a gaze-centered reference frame ( For touch, it has been suggested that the construction of spatial location is 49 an automatic process, implying that any tactile input is remapped into an external 50 code, irrespective of its relevance (Heed & Azañón, 2014; Röder et al., 2004) . The 51 most common experimental manipulation underlying this claim is limb crossing. 52

Crossing, say, a right arm over to the left side of space leads to different skin-53 based (here: right body side) and external (here: left side of space) spatial codes 54 of a tactile stimulus delivered to the right hand. A task-irrelevant tactile stimulus 55 delivered to a crossed right hand accelerates visual discrimination in the right 56 visual field if it precedes the visual target stimulus by 60 ms, but on the left side if 57 it leads by 180 ms or more (Azañón et al., 2010; Azañón & Soto-Faraco, 2008) . 58

Thus, responses to visual targets were faster after anatomically congruent tactile 59 cues (e.g., tactile stimulus on [crossed] right hand, visual target in right hemifield) 60 at short cue-stimulus intervals, but after externally congruent tactile cues (e.g., 61

tactile stimulus on the left hand crossed over to the right side, visual target in right 62 field) at long cue-stimulus intervals. Such effects are usually interpreted as 63 evidence that tactile remapping -the precise computation of the external tactile 64 confusion is much more prominent when the arms are in a crossed than uncrossed 73 posture. This is surprising because the TOJ task asks about the identity of the 74 touched limb, and, in theory, it would be irrelevant to this question where the hand 75 was in space. That limb crossing, nevertheless, affects TOJ implies that posture 76 cannot be strategically ignored, but is automatically incorporated into the hand 77 assignment. 78

Several explanations have been put forward to account for crossing effects 79 in tactile localization. First, it has been suggested that touch location, once it is 80 remapped, is retained only in an external spatial code, and the original skin location 81 is discarded in the process. To report which body part has been touched, the brain 82 must then reversely determine which limb was located at the computed external 83 location at the time of the touch (Kitazawa, 2002; Kitazawa et al., 2008; Yamamoto 84 & Kitazawa, 2001) . We refer to this suggestion as the space-to-limb reconstruction 85 hypothesis. When applied to errors in the TOJ task, this hypothesis implies that 86 participants correctly remap the two tactile stimuli into external space, but then 87 reconstruct erroneously which hand was at the first spatial location. 88

A second explanation assumes that TOJ errors reflect the conflict between 89 different codes used for stimulus location. When the limbs are crossed, skin-based 90 and external spatial codes point to different sides of space, and this conflict must 91 be resolved, a process that takes time and is error-prone (Röder, Kusmierek, 92 Spence, & Schicke, 2007; Simon, Hinrichs, & Craft, 1970) . In this view, the TOJ 93 crossing effect is a marker for the presence of conflict and, thus, for the fact that 94 remapping into an external spatial code has taken place. Notably, the interpretation 95 that the TOJ crossing effect derives from a remapped stimulus location is indirect 96 because participants only report a binary decision about which hand was 97 stimulated, not the spatial location of the perceived stimulus. Increasing the 98 distance between the uncrossed hands can slightly reduce errors in TOJ (

In turn, this conclusion is incompatible with the common view that crossing 535 effects, obtained in experiments that require categorical decisions such as TOJ, 536

are an implicit indicator of precise tactile localization and, thus, tactile remapping. 537 This is a seemingly surprising conclusion given that limb crossing quite obviously 538 creates conflict between the anatomical body side and the side of space, and it is 539 a strong claim that seems to invalidate the experimental logic of numerous papers 540 that have applied this logic. Our conclusion is, however, in fact compatible with 541 that of another recent study in which participants performed TOJ of tactile stimuli 542 presented to the hands and feet (Badde et al., 2019) . In that study, stimuli were 543 presented to two of the four limbs (hands and feet), but it was unknown to the 544 participant which two limbs would be stimulated in a given trial. Accordingly, four 545 rather than just two response options were always available. In a percentage of 546 trials, participants systematically assigned the first touch to a limb that had not 547 received a tactile stimulus at all during the respective trial. For instance, after 548 stimulation of the left hand and the right foot, a participant may have indicated that 549 the first stimulus had occurred on the right hand. These errors depended on 550 whether the arms and/or legs were crossed. Importantly, neither the side of space 551 of the limb that had received the correct stimulus, nor the spatial distance between 552 stimulus and response limb, were indicative of the erroneously chosen, 553 unstimulated limb -again incompatible with the prevailing view that crossing 554 effects reflect conflict during the integration of anatomical and spatial stimulus 555 location. Instead, participants responded with unstimulated limbs that occupied the 556 space anywhere around the body side of the correct, first tactile stimulus, 557 independent of whether that limb was crossed or not. Thus, what mattered for limb 558 assignment was not the precise, spatial location of the stimulus, but much broader, 559 global spatial stimulus features such as an entire side of the body and its 560 surrounding space. Critically, these global features explained behavior without 561 . Apparatus, task and procedure 770

Kinematic data of the fingers was recorded using an optical motion capture system 771 (Visualeyez II VZ4000v, Phoenix Technologies Inc, Vancouver, BC, Canada) at 772 250Hz sampling frequency with markers placed on the nail of the two index fingers. 773

The experiment was controlled with Matlab (The MathWorks Version R2015a; 774 Natick, MA, USA) using the Psychophysics Toolbox (Brainard, 1997) . Stimulus 775 presentation was controlled via custom-made hardware and triggered through a 776 digital acquisition card (PCI-6509, National Instruments, Austin, USA). 777

The procedure was largely similar to Experiment 1, except that 1) participants 778 made only reaches from an uncrossed to an uncrossed posture or from a crossed 779 to a crossed posture and 2) tactile stimuli were separated by SOAs of 60, 85, 110, 780 or 135 ms. Posture was varied in blocks of 64 trials in a pseudo-randomized order. 781

Within each block, SOA and which hand was stimulated first were pseudo-782 randomized. Participants performed 28 blocks (14 of each posture combination) 783 for a total of 1792 trials. The space-to limb reconstruction hypothesis 243 posits that the spatial location of the first tactile stimulus is represented correctly, 244 and that a limb assignment entails computing which limb was at that spatial 245 location when the stimulus occurred. Thus, in our task, responses with the 246 incorrect hand would result from assigning the incorrect hand to the correct spatial 247 location of the first tactile stimulus (see Fig. 1B). Accordingly, the chosen, incorrect 248 hand should be directed to the location at which the stimulus of the other, correct 249 hand had occurred, and the reported stimulus location in TOJ error trials should 250 scatter around the movement trajectory of the correct hand. Contrary to this 251 prediction, participants pointed to locations scattered around the movement 252 trajectory of the chosen, incorrect hand (see also Fig. 2B), indicating that the 253 chosen stimulus had been perceived on the incorrect hand (see Fig. 4 for the 254 localization responses of the participant with the largest variability in localization 255 errors). Participants indicated both the target limb and the perceived location 479 in space of the first of two tactile stimuli in a tactile TOJ task. Presentation of stimuli 480 during movement implied that stimulus location depended on stimulation time, 481 allowing us to determine the relationship of stimulus timing and perceived stimulus 482 location in space. If participants had first computed the spatial location, and then 483 derived which limb had occupied this location at time of stimulation (space-to-limb 484 reconstruction hypothesis, see Kitazawa, 2002), incorrect hand assignment should 485 have been associated with external localization along the trajectory of the correct 486 hand; we did not find any evidence for such behavior. If participants had 487 represented stimulus location and stimulated limb together, and simply confused 488 the two due to conflict between different spatial codes (stimulus switch hypothesis), 489 incorrect hand choice should have been associated with spatial localization at the 490 location of the incorrect limb at the second stimulus's time. Localization error 491 curves were incompatible with this view, as their systematic bias differed 492 significantly from a hypothetical localization curve, derived from correct trials, 493 relating to stimulus time 2. Instead, when participants chose the incorrect hand, 494 their localization errors implied that they had aimed at that hand's location at the 495 time of the first, correct stimulus, evident in a close match of localization curves of 496 correct and erroneous TOJ trials when computed relative to stimulus time 1. In 497 other words, participants derived the reported stimulus location by combining the 498 time of the first, correct stimulus with the trajectory of the second, incorrectly 499 chosen hand, effectively indicating a location at which no stimulus had occurred -500 consistent with the time reconstruction hypothesis. This behavior was evident for 501 all combinations of uncrossed and crossed start and end postures, as well as for 502all tested SOAs between the two tactile stimuli. FIGREF20.text: 567 However, this manipulation may have simply introduced an additional, non-metric 568 feature that helped representing the two choice options as different, thus improving 569 TOJ choice based on a categorical feature rather than on metric distance. 570 Similarly, whereas effects of distance between the two hands during a TOJ have 571 been interpreted as implying a metric representation of stimulus location (Roberts 572 et al., 2003; Shore et al., 2005), others have reported such effects only for very 573 small (3cm), but not other (10 cm and larger), distances between the hands (Kim 574 & Cruse, 2001), again suggesting that they may reflect categorically coded spatial 575 features, not metric stimulus location. 576 The reason for the apparent contradiction between previous research and 577 these new findings stems from the fact that typical experimental designs, in which 578 tactile stimuli are presented to the two stationary hands, do not allow disentangling 579 the prevailing view of crossing effects indicating conflict between tactile anatomical 580 and (precise) spatial stimulus location from the view that the conflict apparent in 581 limb crossing must indicate other spatial aspects, such as those identified in our 582 previous study (Badde et al., 2019). Thus, limb crossing paradigms that require 583 limb choices about the origin of touch likely reflect the integration of categorical, 584 tactile-spatial stimulus features. We propose that automatic effects, such as 585 crossmodal, tactile-visual cueing (Azañón & Soto-Faraco, 2008), too, are based 586 on such feature-based processing. In contrast, precise stimulus location is, 587contrary to what has regularly been implied, not among the pieces of information 588 that are integrated for automatic, tactile-spatial coding. Instead, precise location of 589 the tactile stimulus in space is inferred post-hoc only when required. 590

Time reconstruction hypothesis: participants point with the incorrect hand at the location at which that hand was at the time of the 137 -is at odds with the idea that tactile judgments are based on precise spatial 138 remapping. 139 Here, we assessed hand assignment and spatial localization of tactile 140 stimuli presented during movement. Our objective was to test whether TOJ 141 responses mark the use of the stimulus's precise, external-spatial location 142 constructed in response to the stimulus, or whether instead participants estimate 143 the precise stimulus location post-hoc by integrating the hand movement trajectory 144 with stimulus time. In other words, we aimed to directly contrast the three 145 discussed hypotheses for tactile localization: the space-to-limb reconstruction 146 hypothesis, the stimulus switch hypothesis, and the time reconstruction 147 hypothesis. 148 We presented human participants with two tactile stimuli during a bimanual 149 movement and assessed which hand participants perceived to have been 150 stimulated first (TOJ hand assignment), as well as exactly where in space 151 participants had perceived it (tactile stimulus localization). The experimental logic, 152 and its relation to the three tested tactile localization hypotheses, are illustrated in 153 Fig. 1. Because tactile stimuli were presented shortly before, after, and during the 154 time of movement, their precise spatial location depended on their timing relative 155 to the movement. This allowed us to determine the precise tactile spatial location 156 participants had perceived when they had made a hand assignment error in the 157 TOJ task. Contrary to common opinion, TOJ errors were not associated with the 158 location of the second, incorrect stimulus. Instead, when participants chose the 159 incorrect hand, they reported its location at the time point at which the other, correct 160 stimulus had occurred. Thus, participants constructed stimulus location by 161 combining the position of the incorrectly chosen hand with the stimulus timing that 162 belonged to the other, non-chosen hand's stimulus, resulting in reported locations 163 at which no stimulus had ever occurred. This finding invalidates current 164 explanations of crossing effects as being based on the precise, remapped external 165 spatial location of the tactile stimulus. 166
